raw_text:
Desailly backs Blues revenge trip
 
 Marcel Desailly insists there is no chance of history repeating itself when Chelsea take on Barcelona on Wednesday.
 
 The French star was part of the Chelsea side crushed 5-1 at the Nou Camp in the Champions League quarter-final second leg in 2000. "Things will be totally different this time," he told BBC Sport. "Now everyone knows about Chelsea and is a little bit afraid of them. They are one of the major clubs in Europe and the pressure will be on Barcelona." Chelsea have not played Barcelona since that quarter-final tie five years ago. The Blues had looked destined to progress after winning the first leg at Stamford Bridge 3-1, courtesy of two goals from Tore Andre Flo and one by Gianfranco Zola. But they collapsed in the second leg, going down to strikes from Rivaldo (2), Luis Figo, Dani and Patrick Kluivert.
 
 Former Chelsea captain Desailly, who is now playing for Al-Gharafa in Qatar, says there is no comparison between that side and the current Blues team, who are top of the Premiership. "Mentally they are much stronger, even though a lot of their players are young," the 36-year-old said. "We made some mistakes at the Nou Camp in 2000 - a lot of them were individual mistakes. "It would not happen now. This team has a new motivation and a different mentality." World Cup winner Desailly saw huge changes during his time at Stamford Bridge. He was signed for £4.6m from AC Milan in 1998 by Ruud Gullit and went on to play under Gianluca Vialli and Claudio Ranieri. But the biggest change occurred when billionaire Roman Abramovich bought the club in 2003. Desailly says the Russian's arrival helped to instil a winning mentality at the club as well as a demand for success. "The whole of Chelsea is different now - the chairman, the manager and all the players," he said.
 
 "Everything is new and there is a huge determination to win. "Since that game in 2000, Chelsea have gained more experience in Europe and were very close to reaching the Champions League final last season." Desailly is one of the most decorated players in the history of football. He won the 1998 World Cup and 2000 European Championship with France, the Champions League in 1993 with Marseilles and 1994 with AC Milan, two Serie A titles and the FA Cup in 2000 with Chelsea.
 
 He is now winding down his career in Qatar, alongside the likes of Frank Lebeouf, Josep Guardiola, Titi Camara, Gabriel Batistuta and Christophe Dugarry. So he is full of admiration for two of his colleagues from the great Milan side of the mid-90s who are likely to line up against Manchester United on Wednesday - Paolo Maldini and Alessandro Costacurta. "I'm happy that they have managed to play so long at a high level," he said. "I made a vow to Costacurta that as long as he plays, I will continue to play. "And it's amazing that Paolo has managed to play at such a high level for such a long time."
llama3.2:1b: Marcel Desailly says there is no chance of Chelsea repeating the 2000 Champions League quarter-final defeat to Barcelona.
He compares this season's match to their previous encounter, which resulted in a 5-1 loss.
Desailly believes the team has "made some mistakes" and now have a new motivation and mentality.
He praises Roman Abramovich for instilling a winning mentality at Chelsea.
llama3.2:3b: Marcel Desailly believes Chelsea has learned from its 2000 Champions League quarter-final defeat to Barcelona and is now well-equipped to face the Spanish side.
He notes significant changes, including a new motivation and mentality, brought about by billionaire Roman Abramovich's ownership in 2003.
The French World Cup winner also praises his former Milan teammates Paolo Maldini and Alessandro Costacurta for their longevity in the game.
gemma2:2b: Marcel Desailly believes Chelsea will beat Barcelona this Wednesday.
He emphasizes the team's stronger mentality and experience compared to their 2000 loss, highlighting Chelsea’s current success in the Premier League.
Desailly attributes these differences to changes within the club since Roman Abramovich's purchase.
His career includes multiple international titles and he is currently playing alongside legendary footballers like Maldini and Costacurta.
qwen2.5:0.5b: French Chelsea star Marcel Desailly backs the Blues' revenge trip in the Champions League on Wednesday, stating there is no chance of history repeating itself and calling for the club to push for a return to its glory days.

Desailly claims the Blues are the top team in Europe and are currently undefeated, while his current team has not played Barcelona since their 2000 Champions League quarter-final match five years ago.
Desailly says he is happy the Blues have managed to play so long at a high level and wishes Costacurta would continue playing for Manchester United.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Former Chelsea captain Marcel Desailly predicts no repeat of their 2000 Champions League loss to Barcelona, citing improved team dynamics and increased European experience since then.
Desailly also praises Russian owner Roman Abramovich's influence in instilling a winning mentality at the club.
qwen2.5:3b: Marcel Desailly insists Chelsea are much stronger than the side he played against in 2000 and believes they have learned from past mistakes.
He cites Chelsea’s improved mental strength, experience gained since their defeat five years ago, and support of new owner Roman Abramovich as key factors.
Former Chelsea captain sees major changes at the club, including a renewed winning mentality.
Desailly also praises his former AC Milan teammates Paolo Maldini and Alessandro Costacurta for continuing to perform at high levels.

tinyllama:1.1b: Desailly backs Blues revenge trip with Champions League quarter-final second leg in doubt due to Barcelona's recent performance.
The Frequency Star was part of the Chelsea side that was eliminated by Barcelona five years ago but had hoped for a more favourable outcome this time round.
However, Barcelona has since played its biggest game since the 2019 UEFA Super Cup and will be confident of progressing through to the semi-finals.

The Blues have not faced Barcelona in the Champions League since that memorable encounter five years ago, but they have a lot of motivation as they seek to secure top spot in the Premier League and avoid relegation.
Despite having former teammate Paolo Malbini and Alessandro Costaccurta on their bench, Desailly has no doubts about their ability to perform on Wednesday night.
He believes that Barcelona's recent form is "not much different" from that of the previous match between Chelsea and Barcelona in 2000.
However, despite this newfound mental strength, Desailly remains optimistic about the Blues' chances of progressing through to the semi-finals.
